page.title: 06Land Use
page.content: { Street}is built upon slighty rising ground in an otherwise flat,low-lying area of lush moorland,once covered by the sea. Fields to the east of the town are drained by an intricate system of ditches known as{"rhynes".}These flow into the River Brue and enable land normally liable to flooding to be utilized for agricultural purposes-dairy cattle in the main. {Friesian,Jersey and Charolais}comprise the most numerous types.Topsoil in the lowland is rich,dark peat which is dug commercially for sale in garden centres.This peat layer means that year round grazing is available.The regin is criss-crossed by trackways called{"droves".}Where the land rises slightly some sheep are found.Pockets of cider apple orchards remain but they are not as numerous as they were.
